[h1][b]Ultimate Once Human Review ‚Äî The One You Actually Wanted to Read[/b][/h1]

I downloaded [b]Once Human[/b] expecting a casual survival experience‚Ä¶  
Instead, I found myself fighting a refrigerator with legs while my friend was screaming about cosmic butterflies.  
[b][i]10/10[/i][/b] already questioning my life choices.

[quote][i]But let‚Äôs be serious for a moment ‚Äî this game is weirdly good.[/i][/quote]

[h2][b]Gameplay & Progression[/b][/h2]

- Level cap is [b]50[/b], and yes, you can hit it in around 3 weeks even if you play like a normal human and not a sleepless gremlin.  
- Grinding? [b][i]Illegal levels of easy[/i][/b]. Electric tools basically gather everything for you in 0.5 seconds.  
- Dungeons, Silos, and elite enemies usually drop what they promise within a few runs.  
- Best loot? Just solve a simple puzzle ‚Äî sometimes as easy as taking a picture of a statue.

[h2][b]Building & Base Life[/b][/h2]

You can build a [b]modern house[/b], a [b]fortress[/b], a van-home (mobile depression unit), or even a mini-castle.  
And yes, you can move your entire house like it‚Äôs a USB flash drive.  
[i]Peak technology.[/i]

Each region has its own resources ‚Äî deserts, jungles, beaches, islands, mountains, swamps, valleys.  
Tryhards take the resource-rich areas, casual players take the beautiful ones.  
[b]Perfect balance.[/b]

[h2][b]Tech Tree[/b][/h2]

Everything you unlock actually matters: farming, weapon tiers, electricity, crafting machines, and even the cursed gacha machine.  
It looks complicated at first but gets easier as you progress.

[h2][b]Weapons & Combat[/b][/h2]

Play in third-person or first-person.  
Early enemies walk slower than my grandma, later ones actually try.  
Weapons come in two types:  
- Looted ‚Üí you disassemble them  
- Crafted ‚Üí you invest in them

[h2][b]Familiars (The Real MVPs)[/b][/h2]

You can have helpers that farm for you: bowls, onions, teddy bears, cats, balloon dogs, fairies, black holes, energy orbs, and even killer bunnies in suits.  
They work while you‚Äôre offline. Who needs real friends?

[h2][b]Monetization[/b][/h2]

Battlepass is the only thing worth paying for, and even then it‚Äôs just cosmetics.  
Gacha uses [b]in-game currency[/b], not real money. Bless this system.

[h2][b]Story[/b][/h2]

99% skippable.  
The environment explains the world better than the dialogue anyway.

[h2][b]The Bad Stuff[/b][/h2]

[spoiler]  
- Building on slopes will make you doubt reality.  
- Trading system is‚Ä¶ ‚Äúcreative.‚Äù  
- Bugs exist ‚Äî some funny, some annoying (like when bosses refuse to spawn).  
[/spoiler]

But the devs are active, communicate well, and give rewards whenever they mess up ‚Äî which already makes them better than many billion-dollar studios.

[h2][b]Final Verdict[/b][/h2]

Once Human is chaotic, creative, stupidly fun, surprisingly deep, and way more polished than a free-to-play game should be.  
If you enjoy exploring weird worlds, building cool bases, and occasionally screaming at sentient household appliances ‚Äî you‚Äôll love this game.

[b][i]Highly Recommended.[/i][/b]  
Would fight cosmic butterflies again.

[h2]Getting into it[/h2]
It‚Äôs a strange game at first, but once it clicks there‚Äôs a lot of fun here. I‚Äôve put in around 254 hours and even after taking a break, I know I‚Äôll return. It has that ‚Äúone more thing to do‚Äù feeling with building, exploring and upgrading.

[h2]Style and world[/h2]
It‚Äôs clearly an Asian-made game and the aesthetics are great. Outfits, weapons and fashion actually look cool, which is something a lot of Western games forget. The world design is weird in a good way, with creatures, biomes and bosses that feel memorable.

[h2]Servers and progression[/h2]
Each server is its own world with a story and time-gated progress. Join a fresh one if you can, older worlds get quiet near the end. The beginner world is easy but doesn‚Äôt have everything unlocked. Once you understand this system, it makes more sense and gives you clear goals to work toward.

[h2]Gameplay mix[/h2]
You get a bit of everything: shooting, crafting, collecting creatures, dungeons, base-building and exploring. Building is surprisingly fun and some players make insane designs. Bikes and cars make travelling feel fast and satisfying. There‚Äôs also a permanent world where all your progress carries over between seasons.

[h2]Quick notes[/h2]
Combat can be a little simple at times and some systems can feel messy until you learn them, but overall it stays engaging if you like upgrading, looting and creating your own base.

What's more, there's such limited information available about the game - even the people playing the game in world chat give bad intel 80% of the time. I want to start by personally thanking the development team for making this game. What an incredible joy. I just recently bought BF6 and Arc Raiders and I'm just so disappointed in them. They are a constant reminder of the awfulness of humanity. This game, on the other hand, has been nothing but fun. I don't even know where to begin. It's the most elaborate open-world sandbox game I've ever played. I've been gaming since the digital age has existed so I've played all manner of games, but this one is just something else. They took all the fun aspects of every other game and somehow fluidly crammed them all into one incredibly fun game. It's Rust in the Control universe (Control was my favorite game, so this game suits me well). Except it's better than Rust because you get to keep your progression now. I'm going to start a list of all the things I love about this game:
-Combat is surprisingly engaging for how simple it is, you think you're king of the zombies until you're not
-There is a metric butt-ton of building options to make sick bases
-Cosmetics are a bit limiting, you can't dye anything, but what's available is high quality
-Animations are very elaborate while not being cumbersome. They look jank at first, but honestly, it's an incredibly advanced animation system they are using. Try riding a bike in the game, all the animations are so well done and accurate, and the swimming ones are fantastic too. There's even an animation to put bait on your fishing line. On top of that, you aren't put into annoying animation locks like when you're mounting/dismounting your motorcycle; they really understood the assignment here.
-The progression is very well done, it's fairly slow but constant, so I always feel like I'm progressing without seeing the "finish line" (BPD/ADHD people will understand) so it's been great.
-The community is incredible. Games like Arc Raiders and BF6 have players at each others throat, but it's nothing but chill vibes on this game. Everyone is so incredibly kind and actually play together.
-It just feels like a game made by a real gamer. Every game lately has felt like it was made by a disconnected boomer developer that doesn't even play games anymore.

-My only main complaint is that the pet system is extremely cute but obsolete as everyone uses Festering Gel.

I'll come back to this list to add more, but for now, I'm greatly suggesting to everyone to play this game!

The character customization in this game is actually really good, but that's about as far as I got, as immediately after entering the actual game and beginning the tutorial I was blindsided by how insane the default settings and keybinds are. I'm used to having to adjust settings and keybinds when starting a new game. Default camera movement speeds are painfully slow despite my mouse's high DPI settings, but that's simple enough to change in the settings. For some unthinkable reason yet another game has hold-to-sprint as the default, but at least I can change it to a toggle in the settings. So far so good.

But then I got into the keybinds after I noticed some odd defaults, like melee being bound to the v key. The keybindings in this game are extensive, and the menu itself is relatively decent, but the problem arises when you want to use a key that is, by default, bound to multiple different functions. One example is the E key, which I wanted to bind the melee to. By default the E key is bound to about... 6 or 7 different functions, which based on their names are all related conditional functions that aren't available to be used at the same time, so it makes sense they'd all be on the same key. While I was able to bind melee to E, when I then tried to reassign the half-dozen functions that got unbound to V, I was thrown into error hell. For some reason, even though these functions are all bound to the same key by default, you as the player are not allowed to rebind them to the same key. If you try to assign two of these functions to the same key, you are immediately confronted with an error popup stating that something else is already bound to that key, and given the option to either cancel the binding or to continue and unbind the currently bound key.

It drives me absolutely insane when developers do this kind of thing. There is absolutely no reason why the player should not be able to emulate the default keybinding, just with a different key. While I could easily solve this issue using a third party software to leave the terrible default keybindings the way they are and instead remap my actual keyboard, a) I shouldn't have to b) doing so causes its own issues and c) there are so many keybindings in this game that I would need to fix in this way that the end result would be some strange alien keyboard layout that is completely unusable for typing in or out of the game.

It looks like it might be a good game, but the insanity of the default keybindings and inability to properly rebind them is too frustrating for me to try to deal with, so this one goes back in the uninstalled shelf.
